The paper describes the conditions for the preparation of AgMnO2 particles with the crednerite structure without impurity crystallized phases. It was shown that catalytic properties of AgMnO2 in CO oxidation might be different in dependence on the nature of the alkali-containing precursor used. The highest catalytic activity was achieved when using a combination of K- and Na-containing precursors. It has been found that the low-temperature catalytic activity of AgMnO2 increases noticeably with a decrease in the relative silver amount. An in situ X-ray diffraction study revealed a partial release of silver from crednerite structure with the formation of Ag0 particles when AgMnO2 was heated in a CO+O2 mixture to 150–200 °C, whereas heating to 250 °C followed by cooling to room temperature led to the incorporation of silver back into crednerite structure. The low-temperature catalytic activity of AgMnO2 correlates with the amount of weakly bounded oxygen species on the surface. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Crednerite Silver Manganese Catalytic oxidation Low-temperature activity In situ diffraction Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction Silver- and copper-containing mixed oxides with the delafossite or crednerite structure represent a class of promising materials for the field of heterogeneous catalysis [1–4], including various electro- [5–7], bio- [8] and photocatalytic applications [9–12]. The composition of such oxides is described as Ag1+BO2 (or Cu1+BO2), where B is a trivalent transition metal cation (for example, Mn3+, Fe3+, Cr3+, Co3+, etc. [13]), a combination of trivalent (for example, Fe3+/Al3+ [14] or In3+/Fe3+ [15]) or 2- and 4-valent cations (for example, Cu2+/Mn4+ [2,16]). The delafossite/crednerite structure is built up by the alternation of (1) brucite-like layers of jointed BO6 octahedra and (2) planar layers of Cu or Ag atoms [17]. Unlike the delafossite structure, BO6 octahedra in the case of crednerite are distorted due to Jahn-Teller effect lowering the crystal symmetry to monoclinic. Interest to mixed oxides with a delafossite/crednerite structure as catalytic materials is caused by the possibility for optimization of redox and acid-base properties through the modification of defective and electronic structure. For example, in the case of AgFeO2 the partial substitution of Fe3+ with Ni2+ ions increased the concentration of oxygen vacancies followed by the stabilization of additional reactive oxygen species [3]. A similar result was obtained when AgFeO2 was doped with copper ions [18]. In theoretical work [10] it was shown that the choice of B cation(s) nature in the composition of ABO2 delafossite (A=Cu, Ag) may be a successful strategy to obtain materials with specified photocatalytic properties. For the AgFeO2 and CuFeO2 oxides, the key role of surface hydroxyl groups (OH-) as active sites for the peroxomonosulfate activation has been established [19,20]. At the same time, the concentration of OH- groups is defined by the nature of delafossite layers stacking, which might be controlled by the temperature of hydrothermal synthesis [19,21] or the temperature of post-treatment [20]. The correlation between the photocatalytic activity of AgAl0.4Ga0.6O2 delafossite and the presence of a hetero-phase boundary between particles of 3R and 2H polytypes was established [22]. It should be noted that traditional approaches to optimize catalytic properties of delafossite/crednerite particles such as designing various interface structures [23,24], modifying their porous structure [1,25], and changing the crystallite shape [11] might be also applied. Mixed oxides ABO2 with the B3+ cation represented by manganese are characterized by a crednerite structure type. Such materials are promising catalytic systems for low-temperature oxidation processes [8,26]. For example, catalytic activity of the ternary oxide AgCu0.5Mn0.5O2 (B= Cu0.5Mn0.5) in the CO oxidation reaction was observed at room temperature and even under wet conditions [2]. The traditional hopcalite catalyst applied for low-temperature oxidation is also a mixed oxide of manganese and copper, presumably with a spinel structure [27,28], whereas crystallized CuMnO2 crednerite particles are considered as less active than Cu-Mn spinel crystallites [29]. However, the maximum activity of hopcalite catalyst was observed for an amorphous-like CuMnOx structure [30], for which the local environment might be close to that in CuMnO2 crednerite. Unlike crednerite CuMnO2, the catalytic properties of AgMnO2 oxide were poorly studied [7,31], while data about its thermal stability, electronic structure, as well as magnetic and optical characteristics, are presented in detail [7,32–35]. It was shown that the oxide Ag0.9MnO2 reversibly decomposed into a mixture of Ag0 and Mn3O4 particles, while the formation of the initial crednerite structure took place during the interaction between Ag0 and Mn3O4 at 670 °C [32]. AgMnO2 is characterized by the insertion of oxygen excess due to partial oxidation of Ag+ to Ag2+ [7,33], leading to increased electronic conductivity [35]. Taking into account the common properties of delafossite/crednerite-based particles, as well as the catalytic properties of Mn-containing mixed oxides (CuMnO2, CuMn2O4, AgCu0.5Mn0.5O2), crednerite AgMnO2 is also of interest as a catalytic material for potential realization of gas-phase oxidation reactions. In this paper, AgMnO2 oxide with the crednerite structure was studied as a catalyst for the CO oxidation reaction. It has been found that the nature of the precursors used (KOH/NaOH, Na2S2O8/K2S2O8) have an influence on the catalytic properties of AgMnO2 particles. It was also shown that a decrease in the silver content caused an additional increase in the specific catalytic activity of AgxMnO2 samples (x < 1). 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis AgMnO2 samples were obtained by hydrothermal synthesis. Preliminary, two solutions were separately prepared: (1) weighted portions of AgNO3 and Mn(NO3)2∙xH2O were dissolved in 30 ml of distilled water; (2) alkali (NaOH or KOH) was dissolved in 40 ml of distilled water. After the dissolution, the oxidizing agent (Na2S2O8 or K2S2O8) was added to the second solution to correspond the molar ratio S2O8 2–/Mn2+ from 0.5 to 2. Then, the solution 1 was added dropwise to solution 2, which led to the formation of a dark brown precipitate. Then, it was placed in a Teflon-line pressure vessel and maintained at 140 °C for 24 h. The pH value of the final solution was close to 12. After cooling, obtained precipitate was washed with distilled water multiple times, filtered, dried at 90 °C for 4 h, then calcined at 450 °C in the air for 4 h. The additional washing procedure for the calcined sample was applied using distilled water followed by filtration and drying at 90 °C for 4 h. Three series of samples were prepared depending on the combination of precursors used: (1) Na (NaOH+Na2S2O8), (2) K (KOH+K2S2O8), and (3) KNa (KOH+Na2S2O8). Additionally, for preparation of some samples the Ag/Mn ratio was reduced from 1:1 down to 0.85:1 through the changing the molar ratio of silver and manganese nitrates. The samples were designated as AgxMnO2-YS, where x corresponds to the relative silver content (x = 0.85, 0.9, 0.95 or 1), Y reflects the nature of the precursors used (Na, K or KNa), S reflects the amount of peroxodisulfate used (S=50, 100 or 200 in the case of S2O8 2-/Mn2+ = 0.5, 1.0 or 2.0, respectively). The default S value is 200, i.e. AgxMnO2-Y200 is identical to AgxMnO2-Y. More details on the samples designations and the preparation conditions are presented in Table S1 (see Supplementary material). 2.2 Physicochemical characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) data was acquired on an ARL X’tra (Thermo Fisher Scientific) diffractometer equipped with CuKα radiation (λ = 0.154184 nm). X-ray patterns were measured in the angles range 2θ= 10–80° with a step of 0.02° and a speed of 1°/min using a linear detector Mythen2R 1D (Dectris) with an angular range of 7.0°. In situ XRD data was recorded on a D8 Advance (Bruker) diffractometer (CuKα radiation) equipped with an XRK-900 (Anton Paar) camera-reactor. To measure the signal a linear LynxEye detector was used with a 2θ angular range of 2.9°. XRD patterns were obtained in the angles range 2θ= 10–65° with a step of 0.05° and the point acquisition time of 3 s. Experiments were carried out at 25, 100, 150, 200, and 250 °C. The sample was heated at a rate of 12°/min. The gas mixture was supplied at a rate of 120 (for 1%CO/5.7%O2/He) and 20 (for 100%He) cm3/min. ICDD PDF-4 + was used for the phase analysis. Lattice parameters were refined by the full-profile Rietveld method using the TOPAS program [36] and ICSD database. Average crystallite sizes were estimated using the parameters of peak profiles (width, Gaussian and Lorentzian ratio) by the Voigt analysis implemented in the TOPAS program. Calculation of XRD patterns was carried out based on the model of the defective crystals using the Defect program [37]. Photoelectron spectra were acquired using a KRATOS ES-300 spectrometer (AlKα radiation, power of 170 W). The instrument was calibrated by the positions of Au 4f7/2 (84.0 eV) and Cu 2p3/2 (932.7 eV) peaks determined for the cleaned surfaces of gold and copper foils, respectively. To remove the charge effect the positions of the spectra were corrected using the C 1s line for surface elemental carbon (Еb=284.8 eV). The surface composition analysis was performed using the integrated areas of precision spectral lines taking into an account corresponding atomic sensitivity factors [38]. Detail spectra analysis and curve-fitting procedure were carried out using the XPS-Calc software [39–41]. The specific surface area was determined on an ASAP 2400 instrument (Micromeritics corp. USA) using low-temperature N2 adsorption according to the BET theory. The Na and K concentrations were determined using an Optima 430 DV (PerkinElmer, USA) atomic emission spectrometer. 2.3 Catalytic measurements Catalytic experiments were performed in a plug flow reactor with the use of an I1801 (MIDAC, USA) gas-phase FTIR spectrometer to analyze the composition of the reaction mixture at the reactor outlet. The catalyst weight (mcat) was close to 0.33 g, providing a volume of 0.25 cm3. To define the activity, the reaction mixture of 0.24% CO and 1% O2 in helium were supplied with a rate of 200 cm3/min (contact time of 0.075 s). The heating rate was 10 °C/min. Samples were twice heated in the reaction mixture up to 250 °C with intermediate cooling to room temperature. During the first heating various adsorbed and weakly bounded species were removed from catalyst surface. Here, catalytic curves measured during the second heating are presented only. The final cooling of the catalysts was carried out in a He flow (60 cm3/min). To estimate the СО oxidation reaction rate (W) and activation energy (Ea) the starting interval of the СО conversion curve (in the range of 5–20%) was plotted in Arrhenius coordinates. The experiment in the presence of water vapors was carried out at 30 °C in a mixture of 0.01%CO/ 5.0%O2/ 0.5%Ne in helium, supplied at a rate of 100 cm3/min, providing a contact time of 0.48 s (mcat=1.06 g). To add water vapor in the reaction mixture the flow of He was preliminary blown off through a saturator filled with distilled H2O maintained at 30 °C. The TPR-CO curves were measured during the heating of the samples in a 0.2%CO/He mixture supplied at a rate of 500 cm3/min. Heating rate – 5 °C/min. Before the TPR-CO experiments, all samples were preliminary heated in a 20%O2/He flow at 350 °С for 2 h. 3 Results 3.1 The optimization of preparation conditions Hydrothermal synthesis of AgMnO2 samples implies the precipitation from the solution of metal nitrates in an alkaline medium in the presence of an oxidizing agent (S2O8 2-). As a result, particles with different structure in dependence on S2O8 2- amount were formed in an autoclave at 140 °C. In the case of S2O8 2-/Mn2+ = 0.5 ratio (corresponds to stoichiometric for oxidation of Mn2+ to Mn3+ amount) the obtained sample AgMnO2-Na50 was characterized mainly by a crednerite structure (ICDD PDF-4 + 00–060–0300, A2/m, a=5.583 Å, b=2.894 Å, c=6.293 Å, β = 100.6°). However, an appearance of additional lines from side products was observed, for example, a peak at 2θ∼38.1° ( Fig. 1a). It was attributed to the 111 reflection of metallic silver (ICDD PDF-4 + 00–004–0783). To avoid the impurities formation, increased amount of oxidizing agent was used (S2O8 2-/Mn2+=1.0 or 2.0 for samples AgMnO2-Na100 and AgMnO2-Na, respectively). This caused amorphization of the final product (Fig. 1a). However, subsequent air-calcination at 450 °C led to the crystallization of crednerite particles without other crystallized impurity phases (Fig. 1b). Note that in the case of the AgMnO2-Na50 sample, the reflections of Ag0 particles also disappeared after calcination at 450 °C. Nevertheless, for the synthesis of target AgMnO2 samples, it was decided to use an excess of the oxidizing agent (S2O8 2-/Mn2+=2.0) and to perform air-calcination at 450 °C. 3.2 Structural features of pristine AgMnO2 samples Fig. 2a shows the Rietveld refinement of a typical X-ray pattern obtained for silver-manganese mixed oxide with a crednerite structure by the example of AgMnO2-KNa sample. On the presented XRD pattern, relatively narrow peaks of 00L (001, 002, 003) type are observed, while other reflections are characterized by additional broadening. This behavior is due to the presence of anisotropy of the particle shape (the average size of the crystallites along 00L is larger than the dimensions in the ab plane), a developed defect structure, or a combination of these effects. This is the reason for the poor description of the experimental XRD pattern (Rwp=10.9, Rp =8.5) by the Rietveld method (the anisotropy and the presence of defects were not taken into account). Stacking faults are typical defects for the layered structure of crednerite [21,42]. So, a model with a mirror reflection of layers over planar layers of Ag atoms (180° twinning) was considered for crednerite particles. Simulation details are given in Supplementary materials (Figs.S1 and S2, Table S2). Fig. 2b shows simulated diffraction patterns with different probabilities of stacking faults presence (σ). The value of σ varied from 0 (absence of stacking faults) to 0.5 (one twin boundary for 2 combined layers). The combined layer (CL) includes a brucite-type layer of MnO6 octahedra and a planar layer of Ag atoms. Comparison of experimental and simulated X-ray patterns revealed that prepared AgMnO2 particles were characterized by the σ value close to 0.3 (Fig.S3). It corresponds on average to one twin boundary for every 3.3 CL. Note that the σ value did not affect the position and broadening of the 00L and HK0 reflections. So, these peaks might be used to calculate cell parameters (a0, b0, c0) and the average crystallite sizes in the ab plane (Dab) and along the c axis (Dc). Calculated structural parameters, as well as the unit cell volume (V) and the interplanar distance (d001), are given for studied AgMnO2 samples in Table S3. Analysis of these data revealed that the as-prepared crednerite particles are characterized by similar values of cell parameters (a0∼5.61 Å, b0∼2.9 Å, c0∼6.32 Å), interplanar distance (d001∼6.21 Å) and unit cell volume (V∼101 Å3) regardless of the nature of K- or Na-containing precursors. At the same time, the calculated Dc value of ∼6.4–9.2 nm was found to be larger than crystallite sizes in the perpendicular direction (Dab) by ∼1.5 times for all samples indicating an anisotropy of the particle shape. 3.3 Catalytic properties 3.3.1 Influence of precursor nature All prepared AgMnO2 samples were examined as catalysts for the CO oxidation reaction. For all experiments the carbon balance (calculated as a ratio between amounts of evolved CO2 and consumed CO) was generally close to 100% during the heating in CO+O2 mixture except the starting interval of CO conversion curve. In the last case a slightly enhanced carbon balance was related to the desorption of additional CO2 species formed on the AgMnO2 surface at temperatures below 0 °C immediately after switching the reaction mixture to the reactor with catalyst (Fig.S5). Obtained catalytic curves of CO conversion for samples from the Na series are shown in Fig.S4a. According to XPS data the presence of residual sodium was detected on the surface of such samples (Fig.S6). Since sodium might be a catalytic poison for Mn-containing catalysts [43], the additional procedure of Na washing was performed for studied AgMnO2 samples. This led to a noticeable decrease in the Na content on the surface (XPS) and in the bulk (ICP-AES) of the crednerite particles ( Table 1, Fig.S5). Additionally washed catalysts showed increased activity in the CO oxidation reaction in the temperature range < 100 °C (Fig. S4b). Below, catalytic data are discussed for additionally washed AgMnO2 samples only. Fig. 3a shows a comparison of catalytic properties for AgMnO2 samples prepared using various K- and Na-containing precursors with an Ag/Mn ratio equal to 1. The least active AgMnO2-Na sample was characterized by temperatures of 10% and 50% CO conversion close to 116 °C (T10) and 154 °C (T50), respectively. Observed low activity of AgMnO2-Na might be associated with residual sodium in the composition of the AgMnO2-Na sample, despite the washing procedure performed. The use of only K-containing precursors (KOH/K2S2O8) led to an increase in activity, accompanied by a shift of CO conversion curve towards lower temperatures (T10 =80 °C, T50 =118 °C). The highest activity was found for AgMnO2 samples from the KNa series (prepared using KOH and Na2S2O8 reagents). Such samples were reproducibly characterized by noticeable catalytic activity at room temperature, demonstrating values of T10 = 30 °C and T50 = 75 °C. It should be noted that trace amounts of alkaline ions were detected in the composition of washed AgMnO2-K and AgMnO2-KNa samples (Table 1). 3.3.2 Variation of the Ag/Mn ratio It is known that AgMnO2 oxide is characterized by the presence of cationic vacancies in silver positions [32], which might affect the catalytic properties. To investigate this effect, the relative content of silver in the AgxMnO2 samples was changed during the synthesis (x was changed from 1.0 to 0.85). A decrease in x led to a shift in the CO conversion curves towards lower temperatures (Fig. 3b), which was observed for AgxMnO2 samples from both the K and KNa series. The highest activity in the CO oxidation reaction was observed for the Ag0.85MnO2-KNa sample (T10 =10 °С, T50 =60 °С). Note that no traces of residual potassium were found on the surface of Ag0.85MnO2-K and Ag0.85MnO2-KNa, whereas the bulk content of potassium according to chemical analysis did not exceed 0.01 at% (Table 1). At the same time, the residual Na amount in the composition of Ag0.85MnO2-KNa was close to 0.1 at%, while no obvious Na traces were detected on the surface. According to X-ray diffraction data, there was no noticeable effect of the Ag/Mn ratio on the structural parameters of crednerite particles (a0, b0, c0, d001, V), while the crystallite sizes (Dab, Dc) decreased slightly at Ag/Mn< 1 (Table S3). It should be noted that the overall intensity of the diffraction lines gradually decreased as the silver content decreased for both K and KNa series (Fig. S7). Probably, it relates to a decrease in the crystallinity degree of the formed particles with simultaneous increase in the contribution of the X-ray amorphous component. 3.3.3 Specific catalytic activity To compare the activity of the catalysts correctly, it is necessary to take into account the specific surface area, which varied in the range from 20 to 40 m2/g for the studied AgMnO2 samples (Table S4). The specific catalytic rate (W) per surface unit is shown in Fig. 4. The specific activities of the AgMnO2-Na and AgMnO2-K samples were similar at low temperatures (<80 °C), while the total catalytic activity of AgMnO2-K significantly exceeded AgMnO2-Na sample above 80 °C regardless the difference in specific surface area. Both AgMnO2-Na and AgMnO2-K samples were characterized by significantly lower specific catalytic activity than all catalysts from KNa series.The Ag0.85MnO2 catalyst demonstrated the highest specific activity among the K series samples (WT=40∼7∙1014 molecules/(m2∙s), Fig. 5). Among all the studied AgMnO2 samples, the Ag0.95MnO2-KNa and Ag0.85MnO2-KNa catalysts are the most active in terms of specific rate, for which the WT=0 and WT=20 values were close to ∼1015 and 2.5∙1015 molecules/(m2 ∙s), respectively. Thus, data presented in Fig. 4 confirm the conclusion about the influence of the precursor nature (K- or Na-containing), as well as the relative amount of silver (Ag/Mn), on the final catalytic properties of AgMnO2 mixed oxide with the crednerite structure in the reaction of CO oxidation at low temperatures. Note that estimated apparent activation energy (Ea) for studied AgMnO2 catalysts was in the range 30–50 kJ/mol, while the most active samples were characterized by the lowest Ea value near 30 kJ/mol. Based on additional kinetic data (Fig.S8) the estimated Ea values for CO oxidation in O2-free and O2-containing reaction mixtures were similar indicating the surface reduction as rate-limiting step of overall catalytic reaction through, probably, Mars-van-Krevelen mechanism. CO oxidation over AgMnO2 surface was also carried out in the presence of water vapor (2.8 vol% H2O) in the reaction mixture (Fig.S9). Despite the high activity for the first 3 min of interaction, the studied sample underwent rapid and complete deactivation within 5 min. Sequential light-off experiments under dry and wet conditions of CO oxidation reaction revealed the reversible character of AgMnO2 deactivation due to the presence of H2O vapors. It should be noted that mixed silver-copper oxide AgCuO2 with crednerite structure also deactivated under wet conditions during the CO oxidation reaction [44], whereas ternary Ag2CuMnO4 oxide with delafossite structure demonstrated a resistance to water vapors for more than 5 h [2]. 3.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy The surface composition and surface state of the pristine and used AgMnO2 catalysts were characterized by XPS. Typical photoelectron spectra by the example of AgMnO2-KNa sample are presented in Fig. 5. To analyze the silver surface state a modified Auger parameter α′(Ag) was calculated as the sum of Eb(Ag 3d5/2) and Ekin(Ag M4N45N45) [38]. The value of α′(Ag) was in a range from 724.1 to 724.6 eV for the pristine samples, which corresponds to the oxidized silver in the Ag1+ form [45,46]. For silver ionic compounds, the α’(Ag) value is usually less than 724 eV [38,47]. Data presented in Table 2 shows that the Auger parameter of silver for Na series samples (α’(Ag)= 724.6 eV) was on average higher than that for K series samples (α’(Ag)= 724.2 eV), whereas in the case of KNa series intermediate values of α’(Ag) were observed in the range of 724.2–724.4 eV. The observed differences might be related to the different amounts of residual K+ and/or Na+ ions in the composition of prepared particles (Table 1). Note that the most catalytically active AgMnO2 samples from the K and KNa series were characterized by a more ionic silver state on the surface. This might be related to an increase in the total charge of silver (on average for all atoms) or the presence of small amounts of deeply oxidized silver species in addition to the Ag1+ main state. Note that after catalytic tests in the CO oxidation reaction, the silver state did not undergo any noticeable changes (Table 2). For the reliable identification of Mn state the next spectral parameters were analyzed: the position of the shake-up satellite relative to the Mn 2p1/2 component (ΔE1 splitting, Fig. 5c) and the Mn 3 s multiplet splitting (ΔE2, Fig. 5d). Value of ΔE1 for studied samples was in a range from 10.5 to 11.1 eV, which corresponds to manganese in Mn3+ and/or Mn4+ forms [48,49]. At the same time, the value of ΔE2 splitting was varied in a range from 4.8 to 5.3 eV, which also corresponds to the intermediate state between Mn3+ and Mn4+ [48,50,51]. So, manganese on the surface of AgMnO2 particles was presented as a combination of Mn4+ and Mn3+ species. The appearance of Mn4+ might be associated with partial surface oxidation due to contact with air oxygen during samples storage or calcination. After catalytic tests, the ΔE1 value generally decreased by 0.3–0.9 eV, which was accompanied by an increase in ΔE2 splitting (Table 2). This behavior indicated a reduction of Mn4+ to the Mn3+ state as a result of interaction with reaction mixture. The surface Ag/Mn ratio for the pristine AgMnO2 catalysts corresponded to the composition calculated for its synthesis, except for Ag0.95MnO2-Na and Ag0.85MnO2-KNa samples. The surface Ag/Mn ratio typically dropped by 5–10 rel.% after catalytic tests, indicating a slight surface reorganization. In the case of ternary oxide Ag2CuMnO4, small changes in the surface composition were observed as a result of heating in a mixture of CO+O2 [2], while the surface Ag/Fe ratio for the AgFeO2 delafossite after catalytic tests decreased up to 50%, which was associated with the destruction of the initial surface structure [21]. Finally, based on the analysis of C 1 s spectra (not shown) no significant differences in the distribution of carbon species on the surface of pristine and used AgMnO2 catalysts were observed. 3.5 In situ X-ray diffraction data All used AgMnO2 catalysts were studied by X-ray diffraction, which revealed the preservation of crednerite structure and minor changes in structural parameters after catalytic measurements (Table S3, Figs.S10 and S11). For the AgMnO2-KNa sample, structural transformations were studied by in situ XRD during the interaction with a catalytic mixture of CO+O2. During this experiment, the AgMnO2 sample was step-by-step heated up to 250 °C, followed by cooling to room temperature in the reaction mixture ( Fig. 6). To take into account the thermal expansion factor, a similar experiment was carried out in pure He (Fig. S12). The changes in structural parameters for crednerite particles were investigated depending on the heating temperature. The obtained data are graphically plotted in Fig. 7 and presented in numeral format in Table S5. No noticeable structural changes were observed for the crednerite particles at T < 150 °C. The most changes during heating in the CO+O2 were observed in the case of the cell parameter a0, the interplanar distance d001, and the unit cell volume (V). The values of a0 and d001 increased with growth of the reaction temperature up to 250 °C. A similar behavior was observed during heating in He, which might be considered due to the thermal expansion of the lattice. The behavior of the d001 parameter on temperature differed upon heating in the CO+O2 mixture or in He. This difference is associated with the silver release from the crednerite structure as a result of interaction with the catalytic mixture. Thus, the appearance of 111 reflection from Ag0 particles was observed in the range of 150–200 °C. The intensity of this reflection decreased at 250 °C followed by complete disappearance during the cooling to room temperature (Fig. 6). Note that Ag0 particles were not formed during heating in He (Fig.S12). After cooling of AgMnO2 in a mixture of CO+O2 to room temperature, all structural parameters for crednerite particles recovered to values close to the initial ones. Thus, the disappearance of the Ag0 reflections was accompanied by the recovery to the initial structural parameters. In situ XRD data indicated the reversibility of bulk processes occurred with the crednerite structure during interaction with a catalytic mixture of CO+O2. Note that the reversibility of the silver release from the crednerite structure (Ag0.9MnO2) was also observed and discussed in other work [32]. 3.6 Temperature-programmed reduction Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) is a useful method to characterize the reaction properties as well as oxygen mobility and M-O bond strength. In the case of CO oxidation reaction the application of TPR-CO method is seemed to be preferable providing additional benefits in comparison with traditional TPR-H2 study. The TPR-CO curves obtained for AgMnO2 samples are shown in Fig. 8, while the corresponding quantitative data are presented in Table S5. Using the K series as an example, the influence of the silver content (Ag/Mn) on the reaction properties of AgMnO2 and the nature of its reduction was studied (Fig. 8a). As the Ag/Mn ratio decreased, a shift of the main reduction peak (maximum at ∼250 °C) by 20–30 °C towards lower temperatures was observed simultaneously with an increase in the contribution from the high-temperature peak at 300–400 °C. A characteristic two-step reduction of AgMnO2 was observed for samples from the Na and KNa series (Fig. 8b). It was probably related to the reduction of silver (Ag1+ → Ag0) first and then of manganese (Mn3+/Mn4+ → Mn2+/Mn3+). This agrees with the literature data that the bulk reduction of different manganese oxides (MnO2, Mn3O4, Mn2O3, Mn5O8) using CO occurs in the range of 300–500 °C [52]. The total amount of extracted oxygen (the ratio of CO2/AgxMnO2, Table S6) increased with a decrease in Ag/Mn ratio, indicating a rise in the reduction depth of crednerite particles simultaneously with a rise in the mobility of oxygen in the bulk. At the same time, a decrease in the thermal stability of the mixed oxide with a decrease in the Ag/Mn ratio was observed for both K and KNa series. Such behavior correlates with a decrease in the crystallinity degree of crednerite particles according to diffraction data (Fig.S6). For all AgxMnO2 samples, the presence of a low-temperature TPR-CO peak with a maximum in the range of 60–65 °C was observed, associated with the presence of weakly bounded oxygen species on the surface. In order to estimate the amount of such species, the integral area of the TPR-CO curve was measured in the range from 0° to 100°C (Table S6). Note that such area increased in the row AgMnO2-K<AgMnO2-Na<Ag0.95MnO2-KAg0.85MnO2-K<Ag0.85MnO2-K, which was in agreement with an increase of specific catalytic activity in CO oxidation (Fig.S13). Therefore, the surface weakly bounded oxygen, which corresponded to reduction peak with a maximum of 60–65 °C, might be responsible for the low-temperature catalytic activity of AgMnO2 in the CO oxidation. 4 Discussion The most interesting results of this work were related to the influence of the nature of K/Na-containing precursors and the Ag/Mn ratio in the AgxMnO2 composition on its catalytic properties. A general trend was established that the removal of excess amounts of alkali ions led to an increase in the catalytic activity of AgMnO2 oxide in the low-temperature CO oxidation reaction (Table 1 , Fig. S4). It was in agreement with literature data on the deactivation of copper–manganese catalysts due to the presence or segregation of alkali metal ions on the surface [28,43]. On the other hand, the reproducible effect concerning the enhanced specific activity of AgMnO2 samples prepared using both K- and Na-containing reagents (Na2S2O8/KOH) was found (Fig. 3a). Impurities of residual alkali metals were found in the bulk of corresponding AgMnO2 particles (KNa series, Table 1). Total amount of alkali metals close to 0.1 at% was not as high as for low-activity unwashed samples, but also not as low as for washed AgMnO2 samples from the K and Na series. It is known that small quantities of alkali metals are able to enhance oxidative catalytic activity due to a modification of surface properties, whereas its high concentration causes an significant drop in acidity and a decrease in activity [53]. Presumably, the optimal amount of residual impurities (K and/or Na), as well as its particular surface/bulk localization might be the reason of the increased activity of AgMnO2 samples from the KNa series. However, a reliable relationship between the amount of residual alkali metals and the catalytic properties of AgMnO2 samples was not established. It is known that the positive catalytic effect due to the presence of alkali metals in the composition of MnOx particles is considered as a result of stabilization of the active crystal structure [54] or as a result of the modification of Mn electronic state and the improvement of lattice oxygen mobility [55]. Also, singly-charged alkali metals provides the stabilization of Mn3+ ions in the oxide lattice [56]. However, correlations between the K/Na surface amount and the Mn state on the surface for AgMnO2 samples were not be found (Table 2). This was probably due to the extremely low concentration of alkali metals on the AgMnO2 surface (Fig.S14). Nevertheless, the influence of K+/Na+ ions in the bulk on the oxygen mobility of AgMnO2 particles is not excluded. A decrease in the strength of the Mn-O bond may contribute to an increase in oxidation activity [57]. According to the TPR-CO data, bulk reduction of AgMnO2 samples from the KNa series occurred at lower temperatures than for the K and Na series of catalysts (Fig. 8). It indicated the decrease in overall M-O bond strength for discussed crednerite particles. Similar behavior was revealed in the case of samples with Ag/Mn< 1, for which enhanced catalytic activity, especially at low temperatures, was also observed (Fig. 4). The decrease in Ag/Mn ratio was accompanied by a decrease in the crystallinity degree of crednerite particles according to diffraction data (Fig.S6). For less crystallized particles, increased lability of redox transitions might be realized providing a positive effect on the catalytic properties in the CO oxidation reaction. Finally, for samples with Ag/Mn< 1, the appearance of X-ray amorphous AgMnOx or MnOx species with additional contribution to low-temperature catalytic activity could not be rule out [58]. The catalytic activity of Mn-containing catalysts is usually considered in terms of Mn2+/Mn3+/Mn4+ electronic transitions, whereas for AgMnO2 oxide, the possibility of participation of various silver species (Ag0/Ag1+/Ag2+) in the catalytic cycle is not excluded. It is well-known that low-temperature CO oxidation proceeds efficiently with the participation of highly dispersed oxidized AgOx forms [47,59], amorphous non-stoichiometric MnOx structures [58], or composite-type Ag/MnOx catalysts [60,61]. The Mars-van Krevelen redox mechanism involving lattice oxygen is considered as the main route of catalytic oxidation over Mn-containing catalysts [27,58,61]. At the same time, the activation of O2 molecule occurs at Mn sites, which provides reoxidation of the catalyst due to transitions between different manganese species [62,63]. An enhanced stability of CO–Mn2+ requires the higher energy for bond activation compared to Mn3+–CO and Mn4+–CO species [50,64], implying the consideration of Mn3+/Mn4+ redox transition during catalytic CO oxidation at low temperatures as preferable. The addition of silver increases the catalytic activity of Mn-containing systems due to the strong metal-support interaction [65]. This interaction provides the stabilization of silver in the oxidized state due to the diffusion of oxygen from MnOx particles. Similarly to the Ag/CeO2-based systems [47,66], the key role in the case of Ag-Mn catalysts is assigned to the interface formed between silver particles and support. At this interface, silver is in an oxidized state mainly, providing efficient processes of adsorption and reagent oxidation. AgMnO2 mixed oxide with a crednerite structure can be considered as a “bulk-like” Ag-O-Mn interface with similar to supported Ag/MnOx systems nature. Therefore, the catalytic CO oxidation on the surface of AgMnO2 may also be considered in respect of redox transitions between oxidized silver (Ag0/Ag1+/Ag2+) and manganese (Mn3+/Mn4+) species during reaction. According to the in situ XRD data measured in a mixture of CO+O2, the appearance of Ag0 particles at a reaction temperature above 150 °C was accompanied by the preservation of the crednerite structure (Fig. 6). When heated to 250 °C and then cooled to room temperature, Ag0 particles disappeared as a result of its oxidation simultaneously with embedding into the crednerite structure (Fig. 7). So, the transition between Ag0 and Ag1+ species might take a direct part in the catalytic CO oxidation at relatively high temperatures (100–250 °C). It should be noted that the possibility of Ag2+ stabilization as a result of the incorporation of over-stoichiometric oxygen into interstitial sites was also discussed for AgMnO2 crednerite [7]. The appearance of Ag2+ species as a result of the interaction between Ag1+ and residual surface nitrates was observed in the case of supports with high oxygen mobility [67]. This mechanism is quite possible in the case of AgMnO2 particles. According to the XPS data, the silver state on the surface of the most active AgMnO2 samples (K and KNa series) was found to be more ionic (α’(Ag)= 724.2÷724.4 eV) than for the traditional Ag2O oxide (α’(Ag)= 724.5 eV, [41,68]). This may be due to the presence of small Ag2+ amounts on the AgMnO2 surface. At the same time, the reduction of Ag2+ to the Ag1+ state according to the TPR data proceeds at ∼65 °C [67], whereas a reduction peak with a maximum at similar temperature was also detected for AgMnO2 samples (Fig. 8). Such peak corresponded to weakly bound oxygen species, stabilization of which is probably associated with the presence of Ag2+ forms. Moreover, the intensity of the TPR-CO peak at ∼65 °C correlated with the value of the specific catalytic activity of AgMnO2 in the low-temperature CO oxidation reaction (Fig.S13). So, it is reasonable to consider the redox transition between Ag1+ and Ag2+ species as a part of catalytic cycle over AgMnO2. Similar behavior was discussed for other silver-containing systems [67,69]. Note that a decrease in the Ag/Mn ratio for AgxMnO2 samples might contribute to an increased surface concentration of Ag2+ due to the charge redistribution resulting in the enhancement of catalytic activity, as was observed in the experiment (Fig. 3). 5 Conclusion In this paper, a mixed silver-manganese oxide (AgMnO2) with a crednerite structure was studied as a catalyst for the low-temperature CO oxidation reaction. An original technique of hydrothermal synthesis has been developed for preparation of AgMnO2 oxide without side crystallized particles. For it, co-precipitation from a solution of silver and manganese nitrates with an excess of alkali was carried out in the presence of an oxidizer (peroxydisulfate), followed by hydrothermal treatment at 140 °C. The synthesized AgMnO2 particles demonstrated catalytic activity in the CO oxidation reaction at room temperature. It was found that as a result of synthesis using Na2S2O8 and KOH reagents, formed AgMnO2 particles are characterized by significantly higher specific activity in contrast to synthesis using a combination of precursors K2S2O8/KOH or Na2S2O8/NaOH. It was established that the specific catalytic activity of AgMnO2 particles became higher with a decrease in the relative silver content. An in situ XRD analysis revealed a reversible silver release from the crednerite structure, which occurred during the heating-cooling of AgMnO2 oxide in the CO+O2 mixture. The investigation of reactivity and catalytic properties of AgMnO2 samples showed that there is a correlation between the concentration of weakly bounded oxygen on the surface and the specific catalytic activity in the reaction of CO oxidation at low temperatures (<80 °C). It was discussed that stabilization of weakly bounded oxygen species might be associated with the presence of deeply oxidized silver (Ag2+-like), which surface concentration can be increased with a decrease in the Ag/Mn ratio in the composition of crednerite particles. coredata.dc:description: The paper describes the conditions for the preparation of AgMnO2 particles with the crednerite structure without impurity crystallized phases. It was shown that catalytic properties of AgMnO2 in CO oxidation might be different in dependence on the nature of the alkali-containing precursor used. The highest catalytic activity was achieved when using a combination of K- and Na-containing precursors. It has been found that the low-temperature catalytic activity of AgMnO2 increases noticeably with a decrease in the relative silver amount. An in situ X-ray diffraction study revealed a partial release of silver from crednerite structure with the formation of Ag0 particles when AgMnO2 was heated in a CO+O2 mixture to 150–200 °C, whereas heating to 250 °C followed by cooling to room temperature led to the incorporation of silver back into crednerite structure. The low-temperature catalytic activity of AgMnO2 correlates with the amount of weakly bounded oxygen species on the surface.
coredata.dc:title: Silver-manganese mixed oxide with crednerite structure as a catalyst for low-temperature catalytic CO oxidation
